section.title: Coordinate Systems
section.para: This was created using the June 9, 2008 build of GMAT.

section.title: Overview
section.para: Coordinate Systems are critical to GMAT for several reasons. They are what every object represented within the software is referenced to. They are used by GMAT as the basis for which all calculations are made. They also provide the reference for any OpenGL Plot that is created.

section.title: Listing of Objects and Commands that interact

listitem.para: The Thruster object allows you to set a coordinate system as its reference.
In the spacecraft dialog box you may change what coordinate system the spacecraft's position is defined in reference, whatever the state type may be set as.

Coordinate Systems are very key to the display of OpenGL Plots. They rely on coordinate systems to set how exactly the view of the plot will look using both the View Definition and View Up Definition sections of the OpenGL Plot dialog box.

Whenever you may select a parameter using the parameter select dialog box, you have the option of selecting certain options such X, Y, Z, and several others that will require to set a coordinate system for them to reference.

section.title: Using the GUI
section.para: Firstly, you cannot edit the three default coordinate systems. You may add as many as you need to complete your mission. When you add a coordinate system, you will see a dialog box asking you to name the new coordinate system. You may also set its origin and axes type. Depending on the type of axes you set, you will be able to change certain parameters of it. The only difference between the dialog boxes for creating and modifying an existing coordinate system that you have created is that the former will have a field for you to enter the new system's name where as the latter will already be named and not have this option.

listitem.para: This is an option only if you are creating a new coordinate system. This will be the name of the new coordinate system you create.
This is where the origin, otherwise known as the point [[0 , 0 , 0] on the Axes, will be.

This is where you select what type of axes you want for the coordinate system. For a number of these options, there are no other parameters to change and this will be the only changeable option in the Axes group box.
This and the 'Secondary' drop down menu are only changeable when the Axes type is set to Object Referenced.
The Object Referenced coordinate system will always be fixed with respect to this and the Primary object.
If the coordinate system you select requires a set epoch, this is where it will be changed.
Along with the 'Primary' and 'Secondary' drop down menus, X, Y, and Z may only be set when the Axes type is object referenced.

Setting one of these axes to R will mean it is the axis that always points between the two objects. V will be the axis of their relative velocity. These are both expressed in an inertial frame of reference.
Setting one of these axes to N will mean it is the orthogonal axis to R and V.

If the selected axes type changes with respect to another object such as a planet, it may need to be updated every so often in order to maintain a correct position. This value is, in seconds, how much time passes in between these updates.
